page.title: 09VILLAGES
page.content: NUN MONKTON AND MOOR MONK STAND ON EITHER SIDE OF THE NIDD AND TO THE WEST OF THE OUSE. THE AREA LIES BELOW 50 FEET. MOOR MONKTON VILLAGE BEING THE HIGHEST POINT AT 48 FEET. FERRIES CONNECTED THE VILLAGES UNTIL 1945. NOW THE NEAREST BRIDGE POINT, SKIP BRIDGE, (THE ORIGINAL BUILT BY JOHN CARR IN THE 18TH CENTURY) INVOLVES A ROAD JOURNEY OF TWELVE KILOMETRES BETWEEN THE VILLAGES. NUN MONKTON HOMESTEADS STAND ROUND AN 18 ACRE GREEN WITH A WELL MAINTAINED VILLAGE POND, PUBLIC SEATS AND LITTER BASKETS. THERE IS A PERMANENT MAY POLE, 22 METRES HIGH, OF RUSSIAN PINE, REPLACING AN ANCIENT OAK POLE, THE CENTRE OF MAY REVELS UNTIL THE 1800'S. PAINTED SPIRALLY GREEN AND WHITE FOR 1953 CORONATION. THE BASE ONLY OF A VILLAGE CROSS REMAINS.CATTLE AND PONIES GRAZE THE GREEN AND THE SCHOOL CHILDREN USE IT FOR PLAY.
